This MR is part of a series of MRs that refactor code handling the execution of management messages addressed to the same subnet. 
The goal of these changes is to improve the performance of these messages. 

Note: We do not need callback IDs to identify specific `raw_rand` requests, as we will iterate through all existing in-progress requests at the beginning of the round and create replies.

Merge branch 'exc-1430-install' into 'master'

chore: EXC-1430: Register and unregister subnet callback_id for install code

This MR adds the logic which creates a callback id for a new long install code requests at the start of the execution. The motivation behind this change is to make the long running install code visible to the subnet so that the requests can be rejected if the canister moves to a different subnet during a subnet split. 

The pending install_code requests are tracked in a separate field of subnet call context manager. As they do not require work to be done by other IC layers, they are tracked separately.

This MR does not tackle ingresses because they are handled differently. During a subnet split(let's say old subnet A, and new subnet B), only the terminal states are kept in the ingress history. Non-terminal states are dropped from the subnet A and kept only in subnet B. Thus, once the canister is moved, they will eventually transition to terminal states.  

Note: Closed the previous [MR](https://gitlab.com/dfinity-lab/public/ic/-/merge_requests/13501?commit_id=cd02e12844ca4386edc180134fc2093b289b4e74) and open this one following our internal discussions. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!13955
chore: EXC-1430: Register and unregister subnet callback_id for install code

Merge branch 'chmllr/fix-random-beacon-getter' into 'master'

fix(consensus): try to always return the random beacon

Currently, the consensus pool reader only returns random beacons for heights above or at the latest CUP height. As a result, after introducing node statistics, a slow node that gets a CUP before it was able to deliver a batch of a lower height cannot advance its state anymore as they cannot find the random beacon. Such nodes have to sync from a new checkpoint before they can continue.

In this MR we relax the function and make it always return the random beacon from the latest CUP if the specified height matches the CUP height, or whatever we have in the validated pool. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!16026

Merge branch 'stschnei/subnet_splitting_set_lsmt_flag' into 'master'

fix: Use correct LSMT flag for subnet splitting

We previously set the recently introduced LSMT feature flag to disabled
for subnet splitting. In principle it should not matter, but we now
discoverd some pitfalls, where the flag could affect the handling of
some empty files. As we rely on files not changing during subnet
splitting, we should keep as many variables the same as regular replica
operations as possible.

This MR sets the flag in the same way as the state manager would. Note
that the LSMT feature flag is currently always disabled, so no damage
was done by this bug. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15826
fix: Use correct LSMT flag for subnet splitting

Merge branch 'stschnei/lsmt-feature-flag' into 'master'

chore: LSMT feature flag

This MR introduces a new feature flag for the log structured merge tree
based storage. The functionality for enabling it is largely missing at
this point, but will be added in upcoming MRs. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15608
chore: LSMT feature flag

Merge branch 'stschnei/refactor-loading-overlays' into 'master'

chore: Pass overlay files to PageMap::open

In preparation for the new Log-Structured Merge Tree storage, this MR
picks up overlay files from the checkpoints and passes them to PageMap.

As there is no code yet to actually read or write these overlay files,
we then assert in PageMap that we are given an empty list of overlays.

This MR also contains some other light refactoring preparing for LSMT. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15436
chore: Pass overlay files to PageMap::open

Merge branch 'stschnei/copy-metric' into 'master'

chore: Metric for copying ReplicatedState

This MR adds two extra metrics. The first is to isolate the
ReplicatedState::copy part of commit_and_certify, and the second is a
tip handler variant for the manifest computation (for completeness). 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15366
chore: Metric for copying ReplicatedState

Merge branch 'stschnei/hardlink-per-default' into 'master'

feat: [MR-493] Hardlink immutable files

During initalize_tip, we currently reflink copy all files.

Instead, we now distinguish which files need to be writeable in the tip,
and which ones are immutable. The immutable ones are hardlinked.

For safety, we make sure that we only ever hardlink readonly files, and
do not change the permissions of files that have been hardlinked.

This MR also prepares for the LSMT storage layer, where all files are
immutable and therefore can be hardlinked. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!14732
feat: [MR-493] Hardlink immutable files

Merge branch 'mr-488-prefetch-metrics' into 'master'

chore: [MR-488] Additional memory tracker metrics

This MR adds a couple of additional metrics to the memory tracker. In
particular:

1. Number of segfaults handled
2. Number of calls to mmap
3. Number of calls to mprotect
4. Number of pages memcopied from page deltas.

They join the existing metrics of writes before reads, number of
accessed pages and number of dirtied pages.

Also changes all uses of AtomicUsize for the existing metrics to
Relaxed, as we don't really need any ordering guarantees. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!14247
chore: [MR-488] Additional memory tracker metrics

Merge branch 'stschnei/mr-457-prefetch' into 'master'

feat: [MR-457] Simplified prefetch logic in the memory tracker

The interaction between the memory tracker and the underlying PageMap
used to rely on the function get_memory_region. This function would
return a consecutive region that could either be unprotected or the
data of a single delta page. This way, the layout of the delta pages
would affect how large a region the memory tracker would unprotect in
one iteration.

This MR replaces get_memory_region by get_memory_instructions, which
returns a sequence of instructions such that the entire input range
can be unprotected. This new scheme is both simpler on the memory
tracker side and avoids cases where the execution performance would
deteriorate significantly due to the presence of deltas. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!13430
feat: [MR-457] Simplified prefetch logic in the memory tracker

Merge branch 'jason/fix-nns-governance-heartbeat' into 'master'

fix: Avoid calling with_neuron during validation

Previously, `with_neuron`:
1. is called for all neurons on the heap for neuron data validation
2. reads stable storage when the neuron is inactive

Therefore, for inactive neuron copies on the heap, it tries to read stable storage, which causes the heartbeat to exceed instruction limit. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!16230
fix: Avoid calling with_neuron during validation

Merge branch 'jason/NNS1-2416-5' into 'master'

feat: NNS1-2416 Read inactive neuron from stable memory as source of truth

* Step 1: clean up is_copy_inactive_neurons_to_stable_memory_enabled assuming it is true
* Step 2: clean up inactive neuron copying related code assuming migration status becomes SUCCEEDED
* Step 3: change NeuronDataValidator to only validate inactive status
* Step 4: let StableNeuronStore return NeuronStoreError
* (This MR) Step 5: read inactive neuron from stable memory as source of truth 

Some considerations:
- To avoid unnecessary dirty pages when calling with_neuron_mut without actual modification, an equality check is used to make sure we only update when there is a change
- StableNeuronStore::upsert was just for mirroring, now that it's done, we use create/upsert according to the scenario
- NeuronStore::load_neuron becomes the single entry point for reading a neuron (to support with_neuron/with_neuron_mut/remove_neuron) and it can be easily adapted to reading from one source.
- It would be nice to make sure active->active modification won't touch stable storage. This will be addressed in a following MR if possible.
- Cow is used so that it can hold either &Neuron (heap) or Neuron (stable). This is mostly just for with_neuron to avoid clone().

[Previous MR](https://gitlab.com/dfinity-lab/public/ic/-/merge_requests/16132) | Next MR

Merge branch 'jason/remove-inactive-neuron-cardinality' into 'master'

feat: Remove inactive neuron cardinality validation

Since the inactive neuron definition depends on the time, we cannot guarantee every inactive neuron is always in the stable storage. Therefore we should not validate the cardinality.

Alternatives considered:
1. Instead of validating `heap == stable`, validate `heap >= stable`. However, this is already guaranteed by checking every neuron in stable storage has an entry in heap and is inactive.
2. Validate `heap - stable <= C`. It's difficult to come up with `C`, and in this phase it's easy to check whether the cardinality in the stable neuron store (through `governance_stable_memory_neuron_count` metric) is reasonable. The `NeuronCopyValidator` will have to be removed shortly anyway, because we won't have a copy of inactive neurons in the heap.

feat: NNS1-2482 Expose neuron data validation summary through a canister query method

Key idea: we have a list of `ValidationIssue` coming in from each heartbeat and we need to summarize them so that they don't take too much space in (1) heap, while executing (2) response, while being returned through query method. We maintain a `HashMap<Discriminant<ValidationIssue>, Vec<ValidationIssue>` so that grouping & truncation can happen within groups. An alternative is to create explicit fields for each validation, which seems repetitive and unnecessary. Given that we only expect human readers to consume this response, the only issue with the current approach seems to be more awkward tests (need to look through all groups to assert)

Other decisions:
- not exposing this new method to `canister.did`, to help ensure nobody depends on it
- `ValidationIssue::NeuronStoreError` now contains `String`, for candid derive to more easily work
- Might be able to create another type instead of using `Discriminant`, but that seems repetitive
- Other maps with more stable ordering might make tests look better, but: (1) no `Ord` for Discriminant, so we would need to implement Ord/PartialOrd ourselves in order to use BTreeMap (2) indexmap let us use insertion order, but indexmap is not commonly used in IC, and I'm not keen on introducing another dependency

Size increase: 
- governance: 2593646 -> 2607044 (13398B)
- governance_test: 2773058 -> 2800000 (26942B) 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15248

Merge branch 'NNS1-2581' into 'master'

fix(nns): Correctly enforce the minimum_icp_xdr_rate when rewarding node providers

At the surface, this change only requires a few lines of code in the `get_monthly_node_provider_rewards method`. However, properly testing it necessitated many more lines of changes. The changes can be summarized as follows:

1. The methods `get_node_providers_monthly_xdr_rewards` and `get_average_icp_xdr_conversion_rate` were initially using the raw dfn core APIs instead of the governance's `env` trait. They have been updated to use the env trait to enable the mocking of inter-canister calls to properly test the core changes.
2. The test `test_automated_node_provider_remuneration` had been disabled during the launch of the exchange rate canister due to the inability to backfill exchange rate data. To ensure that the refactors I was making would not break other code, I had to re-enable this test. To achieve this, I converted the integration test to use a StateMachine, which is a worthy refactor even when considered separately from the task at hand. This allowed all canisters to have their internal clocks accelerated when needed.

Closes NNS1-2581

Merge branch 'jason/NNS1-2474-1' into 'master'

refactor: NNS1-2474 Separate structs for GovernanceProto on the heap

Notes for reviewers: 

Overall structure: NNS1-2474 changes the structure of `Governance` data on the heap (while it does not change its serialization format `GovernanceProto` (More details in [this section of the doc](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1iVNOfXTgQ0CzRuuT_4vLrllQzMmG6a7uluudc24EBjM/edit#heading=h.pd3a4gkxa42z))This is a relatively large refactoring effort, so it's broken down into a few steps to make reviews easier:
1. (This MR) Define HeapGovernanceData and NeuronStore, do conversion between them and GovernanceProto, while everything else is mostly a replacement:`.proto.neurons` -> `.neuron_store.neurons`
2. Move neuron-related methods in the `Governance` into `NeuronStore`
3. Move `NeuronStore` into a new file and create a neuron sub-directory and move neuron-related components into it
4. Refactor NNSState to contain `heap_data` and `neurons` separately, currently it still contains `governance_proto` just for parity - it makes less sense to use `governance_proto` to represent 'NNS State' since `GovernanceProto` represents heap memory, and 'NNS State' should contain stable memory too.

Choices made in this MR:
1. The concept 'database' in my mind tie too much to a traditional database usually outside of the application, which is not the case for data stored in heap/stable memory. 'NeuronStore' seems a better name.
2. `HeapGovernanceData` seems to capture its meaning better than 'GovernanceProtoWithoutNeurons' or 'LiveGovernanceProto' - 'Proto' is avoided since it's not a `prost::Message` by design - it cannot be serialized.
3. Test coverage: the following tests fail if I intentionally break pre_upgrade by not serializing proposals: //rs/nns/integration_tests:integration_tests_test_src/governance_memory_migration_test, //rs/nns/integration_tests:integration_tests_test_src/root, //rs/nns/integration_tests:integration_tests_test_src/reinstall_and_upgrade 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!14028
refactor: NNS1-2474 Separate structs for GovernanceProto on the heap

Merge branch 'jason/NNS1-2479' into 'master'

feat: NNS1-2479 Change NNS Governance neurons from HashMap to BTreeMap

Why this is needed: a well-defined iteration order makes neuron/indexes migration easier - we can use a key as a marker for the migration progress. In general, any work on all neurons can be more easily batched with a BTreeMap.

Why this is safe:
1. There is no change in .proto - their wire format should be the same
2. The iteration order is different, but no code should be relying on HashMap iteration order anyway.
3. Lookup time changed from O(1) -> O(log(n)), 20% penalty measure [here](https://gitlab.com/dfinity-lab/public/ic/-/merge_requests/14105) 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!14104

commits.message:
Merge branch 'fix_blockmaker_metrics_pruning_logic' into 'master'

Fix: Fix BlockmakerMetricsTimeSeries pruning logic

The pruning now happens just before a new snapshot is inserted. If a node ID's stats are equal in this new snapshot compared to the previous snapshot, it is pruned. Since such a node ID is now missing from at least one snapshot (even if it reappears right after pruning) and the pruning process only ever involves two consecutive snapshots, it is no longer possible to have a pruning process mixing up two different series (i.e. with a restart somewhere in between).

Previously, the pruning process was only triggered once the metrics reached full capacity, but since pruning no longer involves the first and last element, this requirement is dropped. As a consequence, it was also possible to simplify both the production code and the pruning test. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!16018
Fix: Fix BlockmakerMetricsTimeSeries pruning logic

Merge branch 'fix_output_queue_proptest' into 'master'

Fix: Fixes a proptest that was missing it's test clause.

The test was essentially attempting to verify the production's logic with itself. It was bugged, which wasn't noticed due to the missing `#[test]` clause.

The test is kept conceptually as it was before except there is an additional `prop_assert!` for the invariants at the bottom to ensure the test won't just silently pass if the production code is modified in such a way that the invariants are violated and the implicit check for them was removed at the bottom of `OutputQueue::push_request()`. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15993

Merge branch 'add_call_graph_depth_field_for_requests' into 'master'

Feat: MR-485 Define optional `metadata` field in `Request`, not yet populated.

This adds a new field `metadata` to `Request`, which is intended as a container for current and future metadata. For now it holds `call_tree_depth`, `call_tree_start_time` and `call_subtree_deadline`.

Due to the rather cumbersome rollout nature of adding new fields to messages, these fields are what we think could be useful in the foreseeable future. The next step would be to have them set on inception and then use them for metrics to provide a clearer picture as to which steps should be undertaken downstream. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!13591

commits.message:
Merge branch 'pakhomov/manifest_inodes' into 'master'

feat: Use inode to account for unchanged files in incremental manifest computation

We can reuse hashes of read-only files, the caveat is we need to be sure we didn't remove and recreate them. Instead of trying to figure out wether we did, we can leverage the fact that we hard-link them from the previous checkpoint to the new one (via tip). If a file in old checkpoint and in new checkpoint points to the same data, we may skip rehashing. The way to check if two files are hard links to the same data is checking their inode number + device number to be extra sure they are on the same filesystem. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15834
feat: Use inode to account for unchanged files in incremental manifest computation

Merge branch 'pakhomov/state_manager_check_tip_thread' into 'master'

fix: Check liveness of the Tip thread in debug

If the Tip thread panics, the tests may succeed unless they try to communicate with it. Which leads to tests that fail a debug assertion, print a panic and succeed. Now we check for liveness of the Tip thread in StateManager Drop 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15418
fix: Check liveness of the Tip thread in debug

commits.message:
Merge branch 'paulliu/ingress-handler-use-time-source' into 'master'

fix: Replace current_time with time_source so that it can be mocked properly in benchmark

The handle_ingress benchmark relies on mocked time in order to measure the right thing (ingress messages properly validated and become part of ingress history). Unfortunately it was never noticed because our CI do not catch benchmark anomalies.

This MR fixes the problem by replacing current_time with time_source that can be controlled in a test or benchmark setup. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15962
fix: Replace current_time with time_source so that it can be mocked properly in benchmark

Merge branch 'paulliu/disable-multiple-nodes-are-deterministic-test' into 'master'

test(consensus): Disable multiple_nodes_are_determinstic test

The test still occasionally fails, and the problem should be investigated and fixed before enabling it again. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!14452
test(consensus): Disable multiple_nodes_are_determinstic test

Merge branch 'paulliu/re-enable-determinstic-consensus-test' into 'master'

test(consensus): Re-enable multiple_nodes_are_deterministic test

Re-enable determinstic consensus test after !13010 is merged. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!14429
test(consensus): Re-enable multiple_nodes_are_deterministic test

Merge branch 'paulliu/consensus-cache-finalized-blocks' into 'master'

feat(consensus): use cached finalized blocks in chain iterator

Use cached finalized block chain when iterating blocks, which saves block loading and deserialization time.

A new interface `chain_iterator(..)` is added to the `ConsensusPoolCache` trait, and `CachedChainIterator` is implemented as looking up cached finalized blocks before looking up blocks in the pool.

Remove `BlockChainIterator` and replace it usage by the old `ChainIterator` interface (so that cached implementation can be used).

Optimize the usage of `BlockPayload` by always using the `AsRef` instance, and eliminated the use of `From` instance. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!13576
feat(consensus): use cached finalized blocks in chain iterator

Merge branch 'FI-1001-sync-ledger-metadata' into 'master'

feat(FI-1001): Sync ledger metadata into table

The MR completes the following:
- Sync the metadata from the ledger canister to a `metadata` table in online mode.
- In offline mode, two new arguments are required (`icrc1-symbol` and `icrc1-decimals`) in order to be able to create a `Currency` object.
- If the node was previously online and then switched to offline mode, the arguments are compared against the metadata found in the `metadata` table to ensure correctness. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15327
feat(FI-1001): Sync ledger metadata into table

Merge branch 'rc/network-status' into 'master'

feat(FI-966): Add network status endpoint to ICRC Rosetta

This MR introduces the following changes:
1. Adds a `timestamp` field to the `blocks` table.
2. Adds a `/network/status` endpoint to the ICRC Rosetta.
3. Adds a test for `/network/status`.

The `sync_status` field portion is not implemented as this will require a discussion on how to report the current sync status. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!14994

Merge branch 'mk/system_api_improvements2' into 'master'

RUN-521, RUN-783: Change arguments of system_api host functions to unsigned

In this MR we change arguments of system_api host functions to unsigned where applicable.
The underlying motivation is to reduce a risk of incorrect casts (e.g. from i32 to u64).
These args are meant to be unsigned in the first place.

Additionally removing a "convenience cast" to u64 in the macro, to make it more explicit at call site what conversions are happening.

Merge branch 'mk/system_api_improvements' into 'master'

RUN-521: Refactor non native stable write charges and checks

This MR refactors how we process non-native stable write charging.
It moves the relevant checks out of the common path, so that they are no longer executed in all the other system api calls.
dirty_stable_pages counter has been removed from ExecutionComplexity and is stored explicitly in StoreData. (used only in non-native mode).

As non-native stable is disabled by default, I added a few tests that explicitly check non-native mode. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15411
RUN-521: Refactor non native stable write charges and checks

Merge branch 'mk/inst_pre' into 'master'

RUN-791: Pre instantiate wasm instances during compilation

This enables pre instantiation in wasmtime, which allows to do the linking against system api functions during compilation (instead of instantiation).
https://docs.wasmtime.dev/api/wasmtime/struct.InstancePre.html

Additional explanation:
Wasmtime `Module` represents a compiled wasm module. To create a Wasmtime `Instance` of the module, additionally a `Store` with runtime data needs to be provided. To create a wasmtime `Instance`, wasmtime `Linker` is used, which links precompiled wasmtime module and optionally other modules, in our case system api host functions. `InstancePre` is a structure that represents an instance just before it was instantiated, after all type-checking and imports have been resolved. The only thing left to do for this instance is to actually run the process of instantiation. By creating `InstancePre`, and storing it in embedders cache instead of wasmtime `Module`, we save time on importing/linking/type checking system_api functions during actual instantiation.

Benchmarks as well as testnet experiments show 30-40% improvement in execution time of very light wasm functions (like counter canister) 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15029
RUN-791: Pre instantiate wasm instances during compilation
[RUN-792] Enable new WASM metering on Application subnets

Merge branch 'mk/pretry3' into 'master'

Refactoring and cleanups of system_api

This MR contains SystemApi cleanup/changes which are necessary for InstancePre functionality in wasmtime. (a follow-up MR will enable InstancePre itself). It may however be considered a separate change which we want regardless of InstancePre.


InstancePre functionality allows to do the linking against system api functions during compilation (instead of instantiation).

For this to work, all the runtime data that was previously captured in closures, now needs to be extracted and put into DataStore (which is a runtime object, required for instantiation, but not linking).

However, DataStore type needs to be known during linking.
Consequently, DataStore can no longer be a generic type (it was previously templated with SystemApi trait). This leads to removal of SystemApiEmpty variant - we always use SystemApiImpl. Empty was replaced by Option::None.
(alternatively we could implement a dummy SystemApiImpl object, and get rid of the option and unwraps; not done now, because it's not trivial)

The mentioned data separation leads to some simplifications of the linking function (system_api.rs:syscalls) 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!14577
Refactoring and cleanups of system_api

Merge branch 'rjb/custom-domains-system-test' into 'master'

feat(BOUN-546): Custom Domains System Test

This is the first MR of adding a comprehensive end-to-end test for custom domains. This MR just sets up the required infrastructure and adds a manual test to demonstrate that it works as intended.

The MR consists mostly of three changes:
* Changes to the Boundary Node and its services to facilitate testing. For example, we had to extend the certificate issuer such that it allows to configure a specific DNS resolver instead of the system one. These changes are mostly under `ic-os/boundary-guestos/...` and `rs/boundary_node/certificate_issuance/certificate_issuer/...`.
* Changes to the farm driver for the Boundary Node to pass in all the configurations required for custom domains. Now, it is possible to specify specific nameservers for IPv4 and IPv6 instead of the default ones.
* Introduction of the actual test infrastructure. As custom domains involves several "outside" services, the changes are quite involved and we explain them in more detail below.

_Test Infrastructure_
Custom domains has three external dependencies: a DNS resolver to lookup user configurations, Cloudflare as a DNS provider to perform DNS challenges, and a ACME provider to request TLS certificates.

For the test, we mock all three of these dependencies in a single UVM. Within the UVM, multiple docker containers are started: coredns as DNS resolver, Cloudflare API to mock Cloudflare, Pebble as a ACME provider, and Pebble Cache as a shim between the Boundary Node and Pebble.

All the code to setup the test infrastructure is located in `rs/tests/src/custom_domains_integration/setup.rs`. The actual tests are located in `rs/tests/src/custom_domains_integration/certificate_orchestrator.rs`. So far, we have a single test that registers a custom domain and demonstrates the functionality of the setup.

As follow-up, we will create more tests and move the test from `manual` to a pipeline that is run regularly. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!13302

Merge branch 'bartosz/NNS1-202-blocking' into 'master'

feat(crypto): NNS1-202: enabling node crypto keys invariants in a blocking way.

Switching "soft" invariants into "hard" (i.e. blocking) ones.
The soft invariants were enabled on the mainnet over a month ago, and according to logs the were no invariant violations since then.  In the last 40 days (as of Aug. 17, 10:38am Zurich time): 
- there are 15'691 log entries labelled `crypto_soft_invariants_check_start` ([link](https://kibana.mainnet.dfinity.network/app/discover#/?_g=(filters:!(),refreshInterval:(pause:!t,value:60000),time:(from:now-40d,to:now))&_a=(columns:!(),filters:!(),hideChart:!f,index:'020df008-22af-44a5-b410-3e6e3a3b4f2c',interval:auto,query:(language:kuery,query:crypto_soft_invariants_check_start),rowsPerPage:500,sort:!(!(timestamp,desc)),viewMode:documents)))
- there are 15'691 log entries labelled `crypto_soft_invariants_check_success` ([link](https://kibana.mainnet.dfinity.network/app/discover#/?_g=(filters:!(),refreshInterval:(pause:!t,value:60000),time:(from:now-40d,to:now))&_a=(columns:!(),filters:!(),hideChart:!f,index:'020df008-22af-44a5-b410-3e6e3a3b4f2c',interval:auto,query:(language:kuery,query:crypto_soft_invariants_check_success),rowsPerPage:500,sort:!(!(timestamp,desc)),viewMode:documents)))
- there are 0 log entries labelled `crypto_soft_invariants_check_failure` ([link](https://kibana.mainnet.dfinity.network/app/discover#/?_g=(filters:!(),refreshInterval:(pause:!t,value:60000),time:(from:now-40d,to:now))&_a=(columns:!(),filters:!(),hideChart:!f,index:'020df008-22af-44a5-b410-3e6e3a3b4f2c',interval:auto,query:(language:kuery,query:crypto_soft_invariants_check_failure),rowsPerPage:500,sort:!(!(timestamp,desc)),viewMode:documents)))

Therefore it seems safe to switch to blocking mode.

Closes NNS1-202

Merge branch 'kpop/chores/log_errors_in_orchestrator' into 'master'

chore(orchestrator): don't throw away the errors

It will help with debugging failures like
```
Nov 17 13:10:26 localhost orchestrator[902]: thread 'main' panicked at 'Failed to create dir: "/var/lib/ic/data/images"', 
``` 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!16178
chore(orchestrator): don't throw away the errors

Merge branch 'kpop/chores/fix_eq' into 'master'

fix(consensus): make the implementations of `PartialEq` and `PartialOrd` for `consensus::tests::framework::Message` consistent

As pointed out by @roman-kashitsyn in https://gitlab.com/dfinity-lab/public/ic/-/merge_requests/16081#note_1650083213, currently, it might happen that `partial_cmp(message_1, message_2) = Some(Equal)` even when `message_1  message_2`, which violates the consistency requirement of `PartialOrd` and `PartialEq` (see [the documentation](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/cmp/trait.PartialOrd.html)).

This MR fixes it. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!16122
fix(consensus): make the implementations of `PartialEq` and `PartialOrd` for `consensus::tests::framework::Message` consistent

Merge branch 'kpop/chores/remove_dead_code' into 'master'

chore(consensus): remove the `allow(dead_code)` attributes from Consensus production code

Removed the `allow(dead_code)` attributes from `//rs/consensus/`.

Along the way:
1. Removed several unused functions/arguments/fields
2. Moved `resolve_sig_inputs_refs` in ecdsa/signer.rs to a `test` mod, because it's only used by tests
3. Added a test case to cover `TranscriptLoadStatus::Failure` (otherwise the linter complained about `TestTranscriptLoadStatus::Failure` being never constructed)

Note: there is still some `allow(dead_code)` in `rs/consensus/test/framework` 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!16120
chore(consensus): remove the `allow(dead_code)` attributes from Consensus production code

Merge branch 'kpop/CON-1163/system_test' into 'master'

test(consensus): [CON-1163, ICSUP-3734] Add a system test for membership changes

In the test we start with a subnet with a single node and keep adding nodes to the subnet, one at the time, until we have seven nodes in the subnet. After each node is added, we check whether the subnet is making progress.

This will hopefully catch a bug causing [ICSUP-3733](https://dfinity.atlassian.net/browse/ICSUP-3733)

Merge branch 'kpop/cups_refs_2' into 'master'

chore(consensus): small changes to the `CatchUpPackage` interface

In `replica::set_ic_stack::construct_ic_stack`:
1. Change the type of the `catch_up_package` argument from `CatchUpPackage` to `pb::CatchUpPackage` to avoid `pb::CatchUpPackage` -> `CatchUpPackage` -> `pb::CatchUpPackage` conversion roundtrip. **Such a conversion roundtrip could change the byte representation of the serialized CUP's content, if the CUP was produced at a different replica version, which we want to avoid.**

In `consensus::dkg::make_registry_cup`:
1. Return the Rust version of `CatchUpPackage` instead of its proto representation, since all the callers do `CatchUpPackage::try_from` on the result anyways.
2. Make the `logger` argument required, to simplify the function a bit.


In `types::consensus::catch_up_package`:
1. Make the field in `CatchUpContentProtobufBytes` private, and implement the `From<pb::CatchUpPackage>`  trait for it as the only way to instantiate it 
2. Minor adjustments to some comments

In orchestrator:
1. Some minor simplifications 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15967
chore(consensus): small changes to the `CatchUpPackage` interface

chore(consensus): Remove a log message from `consensus::dkg::make_registry_cup`

This message is printed every 10 seconds for ECDSA subnets, it doesn't bring much value, and it can cause confusion, as it's suggests that we are creating a CUP every 10 seconds, but in fact we are only checking what's the most recent recovery CUP in the registry.

Merge branch 'kpop/CON-1123/artifacts_names' into 'master'

feat(consensus,backup): [CON-1123, CON-1126] Remove hashes from the backed up artifact names

Thanks to https://gitlab.com/dfinity-lab/public/ic/-/merge_requests/14658 we now back up only one block proposal and notarization per height, so it's not necessary to encode the artifacts' hashes in the filenames anymore, because there won't be any filename collisions.

On the `ic-backup` side, we now will download only one artifact per type and height (except when the downloaded artifact fails the validation, in which case we will download the artifact again from a random replica), whereas before we would download possibly multiple such artifacts:

Merge branch 'kpo/CON-1124/new_strategy' into 'master'

feat(ic-backup): [CON-1124] preserve only the states from the last three days in the hot storage.

Currently the `ic-backup` moves the states to the cold storage only when the backed up subnet has been upgraded. When the upgrade happens, the tool moves the states from the hot storage to the cold storage, from the *oldest* replica version. Since the tool computes the state and stores it in the hot storage multiple times per day, and each state can be quite big, eventually we might run into problems of running out of disk space, if an upgrade hasn't happened in a long time.

In this MR we change the way we cold store the states. Instead of doing it after an replica upgrade, we move the states to cold store after each `ic-replay` invocation and only keep the states from the last three days in the hot storage.

Example (Note: I hacked the `BackupHelper` a little here and do the `ic-replay` every minute but for the purpose of cold storing I tell the `BackupHelper` that we are doing `ic-replay` only twice per day):

Merge branch 'kpop/CON-1099/validator_2' into 'master'

feat(subnet-splitting-tool): [CON-1099] add a command to `subnet-splitting-tool` which will validate some of the artifacts produced during the subnet splitting

Add a command to `subnet-splitting-tool` which will validate some of the artifacts produced during the Subnet Splitting: NNS signed State Tree, original CUP downloaded from the source subnet, and the original manifest of the state downloaded from the source subnet. 

1. Moved the `CUP` verification code from the `ic-replay` tool to the `subnet-splitting-tool`;
2. Made it possible to use the `state-tool` as a library;
3. Directly (instead of calling the binary) use some of the `state-tool` functions in the `subnet-splitting-tool`;
4. Moved the validation code from `steps.rs` to a shared file `validation.rs`.

[1-pager](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1K0xbgokl4poqYKDXfPphc-xypLH0D3hZ9QQd80wBizc/edit)

Merge branch 'kpop/subnet_splitting/small_fixes' into 'master'

chore(subnet-splitting-tool): [CON-1072,CON-1092] Fix flakiness of the `subnet-splitting` system test & apply various small fixes to the `subnet-splitting` tool

1. Fix the flakiness of the `subnet-splitting` system test, by introducing a `thread::sleep` for 15 seconds after halting at a cup height, to allow the orchestrator to create a CUP;
2. Panic if either of the Subnets is an ECDSA subnet or is not an Application subnet.
3. Print registry contents as separate steps
4. Pretty print the registry content
5. When printing the routing table, print the subnet ids instead of "Source Subnet" and "Destination Subnet"
6. Compare the state hash from the downloaded CUP against the hash of the downloaded state
7. Add more prints during validations

Merge branch 'maciej-rosettasync' into 'master'

feat(FI-1063): icrc-rosetta: speed up rosetta startup with existing database

The sql joins in get_blockchain_gaps are quite slow and the startup with existing database for ckBTC ledger (~97k blocks) takes ~20m: `cargo run --release -- -u https://ic0.app --ledger-id mxzaz-hqaaa-aaaar-qaada-cai  -n mainnet --exit-on-sync`. I changed it to a select that searches for blocks that have no next block (block with index+1) and for each such block search for the block with the smallest larger index. With this change the startup takes ~1s. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!16147
feat(FI-1063): icrc-rosetta: speed up rosetta startup with existing database

With this change it should be possible to sync the ckBTC ledger: `cargo run --release -- -u https://ic0.app --ledger-id mxzaz-hqaaa-aaaar-qaada-cai  -n mainnet`. It was previously not possible due to approvals of size u64::MAX, e.g. https://dashboard.internetcomputer.org/bitcoin/transaction/93370

Merge branch 'andrew/generate-network-config-guestos-tool' into 'master'

Feat(NODE-1168): Rewrite generate-network-config into rust guestos_tool

[NODE-1168](https://dfinity.atlassian.net/browse/NODE-1168)

In preparation of adding ipv4 support to guestos, generate-network-config has been rewritten into the guestos_tool and is now called via:
`/opt/ic/bin/guestos_tool generate-network-config`

The logic of the script has remained exactly the same.

An additional command has been added to the guestos tool: `regenerate-network-config`
This command is exactly the same as generate-network-config, but it also restarts the systemd networkd after writing the new networkd configuration. generate-network-config will be run on startup, and regenerate-network-config will be called at runtime by the orchestrator to re-configure the networkd.

regenerate-network-config is not currently being used.

Additionally, this MR includes some minor refactoring to the rs/ic_os/network code 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!16094
Feat(NODE-1168): Rewrite generate-network-config into rust guestos_tool

Merge branch 'andrew/remove-var-from-HostOS-builds' into 'master'

Fix: Strip var path from HostOS/GuestOS rootfs build and fix user account creation

[Node-1113](https://dfinity.atlassian.net/jira/software/c/projects/NODE/boards/189?assignee=6328911461dbef2805bbcee6&selectedIssue=NODE-1113)

There is a nondeterminism issue in the HostOS /var build. To get around this, we are stripping /var from the GuestOS/HostOS root image build, as var gets mounted over by the LVM anyway (see [mount-genrator](https://gitlab.com/dfinity-lab/public/ic/-/blob/master/ic-os/hostos/rootfs/etc/systemd/system-generators/mount-generator)).

However, stripping var causes issues with the user account setups. This MR also modifies the guest/host setup-ssh-account-keys script to assure that the user accounts are properly created, whether account keys exist for a user or not.

Additionally, stripping var causes issues with the filebeat user permissions, so this MR updates filebeat user permissions at runtime. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15049
Fix: Strip var path from HostOS/GuestOS rootfs build and fix user account creation

Merge branch 'andrew/test-remove-sparse-tag' into 'master'

feat(NODE-1112): Ensure determinism in tar commands

[Node-1112](https://dfinity.atlassian.net/jira/software/c/projects/NODE/boards/189?assignee=6328911461dbef2805bbcee6&selectedIssue=NODE-1112)

Change: Add --hole-detection=raw option to tar commands to ensure determinism.

Context: A community member built a HostOS update image with the exact same contents as the HostOS update image we built ourselves, but the update image tar file they produced was different. We identified nondeterminism when the tar file itself is being created. By default, tar uses the system-specific seek method, which can introduce variability depending on the system and the file system. 

Adding the "--hole-detection=raw" will hopefully resolve this. I don't believe it will cause a significant slow-down for CI. However, it may cause a significant slowdown for community image builds. 


Napkin math:

For a file of ~100 GB that's almost entirely zeros (Like a HostOS disk.img):
SATA SSD:
- Read Speed: ~200-550 MB/s.
- Time increase: 3 to 8 minutes

NVMe SSD:
- Read Speed: ~1,000-5,000 MB/s
- Time increase: 0.3 to 1.67 minutes

----------

Test times of tar command with hole-detection=raw and without it on a 100GB hostOS on sf-pyr06
- With --hole-detection=raw: 2m15s, 1m58s
- Without hole detection=raw: 4s, 4s, 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15016
feat(NODE-1112): Ensure determinism in tar commands

Merge branch 'igornovg/icbn-nns-key' into 'master'

feat(BOUN-960): make NNS public key optional

To run `ic-boundary` under an orchestrator we need to make the arg optional.

* `--nns-pub-key-pem` is optional now. The logic for its requirement is the following:
  * If the internal registry replicator is enabled:
    * If there's a local snapshot of the registry (of any version) - we don't need the key
    * Otherwise we need it and panic if not provided
  * if the replicator is disabled - we don't need the key
* The root key which is returned in the `/api/v2/status` response is now taken from the registry snapshot (if one is available)
  * If the current NNS subnet ID matches the mainnet one - then we don't include the key in the response
* Tests updated to match 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!16128
feat(BOUN-960): make NNS public key optional

Merge branch 'igornovg/icbn-minor-fixes' into 'master'

fix(BOUN-953): smaller metrics, fix request size limit, cosmetic changes

* We again went over the edge with metrics on canary, the scrape started to fail - the scrape limit is 50MB. So another round of cuts, it should make them much smaller:
  * A bit less buckets for latency and request/response sizes
  * Split the caching results into a separate metrics since we probably don't need per-node/-subnet details on caching
* Fix the request size limiter, it didn't really work at all due to the way we consume the request body. So remove the layer and apply the limit manually - tested in dev and works as expected. TODO add tests for that maybe.
* Add request concurrency limit to control memory usage
* Move some vars from const to CLI args
* Log only health check errors, otherwise it's too chatty without much benefit
* Various cosmetic changes 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!16014
fix(BOUN-953): smaller metrics, fix request size limit, cosmetic changes

Merge branch 'igornovg/icbn-stale-metrics' into 'master'

feat(BOUN-949): remove stale metrics

Problem: metrics for the nodes that are gone from the registry are still present in the `/metrics` output and scraped. This poses problems for some of the dashboards like `Subnets Health` that derives the health from total count of healthy nodes in a subnet. It also makes the metrics snapshot larger.

To overcome this we:

* Go over the Metric Families that are emitted by the registry
* Search for all metrics that have both `node_id` and `subnet_id` labels present (node can move between subnets over its lifetime)
* Check if they match what we have in the currently published registry snapshot
* Remove the metric otherwise from the output
* Metrics which don't have both those labels are untouched.

\+ test

Caveat: the actual metrics are still in the registry and cannot be easily removed from there ( `Registry` does not allow us to iterate over what it has registered), but this shouldn't pose any real problems. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15963
feat(BOUN-949): remove stale metrics

Merge branch 'igornovg/icbn-registry' into 'master'

fix(BOUN-948): don't publish stale registry versions

When the local registry snapshot is empty (after deployment) - it's not good to use intermediate versions and go online until it has fully synced.

Before we had `last_known_registry_version` variable `control-plane` used to skip any version below that, but it needs to be maintained and is already 6k versions behind.

Approach here is to detect when the versions stop incrementing for some period of time and only then do the initial snapshot publication that brings us online. This MR adds `--min-version-age` CLI flag - once the initial registry version stabilized for that amount of time it publishes it. The default is 15sec and according to my tests is more than enough. After the initial publication this logic is not used anymore.

\+ oneliner fix for `CanisterId` along 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15929
fix(BOUN-948): don't publish stale registry versions

Merge branch 'igornovg/icxproxy' into 'master'

feat(BOUN-935): icx-proxy: allow HTTP replica, pass headers

To be able to pass `x-request-id` from `nginx` to `ic-boundary` and `x-ic-*` routing headers back, the modifications to `icx-proxy` are needed.

Problem is that it heavily relies on `ic-agent` (which gives zero control on the headers). So to make it happen one need to either fork & change it or re-implement it in part.

To avoid this, TLS (Thread Local Storage) was used:

* Wrap the `Hyper` client into a new `HyperClientWrapper` that intercepts requests and responses from `ic-agent` and does header addition & extraction
* Wrap the Axum handler into `handler_wrapper` which uses `LocalPoolHandle` to make sure that the handling of a call is pinned to a single thread even across `await` boundaries

  The chosen thread is guaranteed to execute given request from start to end before switching to the next one, so there should be no race conditions on the thread local variables.
* Use thread-local variables `HEADERS_IN` and `HEADERS_OUT` to store per-request headers in both directions
* Only `x-request-id` is forwarded forward and only `x-ic-node-id` / `x-ic-subnet-id` / `x-subnet-type` are forwarded back for now

Also the HTTP client is configured to allow `http://` urls for replicas to connect to `ic-boundary` directly 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15870
feat(BOUN-935): icx-proxy: allow HTTP replica, pass headers

Merge branch 'igornovg/icbn-fix-logging' into 'master'

fix(BOUN-632): ic-boundary: fix double logging

In certain cases `MetricsBody` callback is being called twice - this causes double logging and double metrics.

Fix that by adding an atomic flag.

Merge branch 'igornovg/icbn-replicator' into 'master'

feat(BOUN-938): ic-boundary: make registry-replicator optional

* Add CLI parameter `--disable-registry-replicator` which disables internal IC Registry replicator
* Dont's send `x-request-id` back to avoid duplicating it ( `nginx` adds it to the reply)
* Change some retryable HTTP reply codes from 500 to 503
* Fix reg version logging issue 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15785
feat(BOUN-938): ic-boundary: make registry-replicator optional

Merge branch 'igornovg/icbn-firewall' into 'master'

feat(BOUN-935): ic-boundary: add firewall generator

Add a bit dirty firewall generator to replace similar `control-plane` functionality to be able to remove it from BN.

* This stuff is to be removed from the code after we move to a a decentralized BN
* The feature is optional and is enabled only if `--nftables-system-replicas-path` CLI parameter is specified
* Firewall rules are only updated when a new registry version is published and contain all system nodes.

  This is nicer than `control-plane` that persisted them with every routing table change, which is not needed at all and only caused too many restarts when the network is flaky.
* Use `reload` instead of `restart` for `nftables` which does not involve flushing all the rules first and re-adding them. See `ExecStop` below

  ```plaintext
  # /usr/lib/systemd/system/nftables.service
  ...
  ExecStart=/usr/sbin/nft -f /etc/nftables.conf
  ExecReload=/usr/sbin/nft -f /etc/nftables.conf
  ExecStop=/usr/sbin/nft flush ruleset
  ``` 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15733
feat(BOUN-935): ic-boundary: add firewall generator
feat(BOUN-935): ic-boundary: add routing reply headers

Merge branch 'igornovg/icbn-tweaks' into 'master'

feat(BOUN-910): ic-boundary health endpoint, jemalloc & other

* Add `/health` endpoint that responds with `202` when the service is Ok and `503` otherwise, to be used with Cloudflare & friends
* Use `jemalloc` as a default allocator, in my tests it shows much less greedy behaviour, let's test it under prod load. Also some metrics from it are published. The crates in Bazel are rather old and we can't easily use newer versions because of some `ic-*` package dependencies that link old version
* Add gauges to `Persist` to record how many nodes/ranges we have in the routing table, remove duration/counter since they're useless
* Remove redundant `service="ic-boundary"` label from all metrics, we anyway have `job` label that gets added on top when scraped. Makes metrics a bit smaller.
* Improve tests
* Some other cleanups and tidy-up 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15364
feat(BOUN-910): ic-boundary health endpoint, jemalloc & other
fix(BOUN-894): accept any uuid

Merge branch 'igornovg/icbn-optimize' into 'master'

perf(BOUN-908): refactor & optimize ic-boundary a bit

This does not bring any features, just some optimizations and cleanups:

* Check registry version and update the snapshot only if it's changed. Previously we just unconditionally did this every 10sec which is a waste of resources
* Rename `RoutingTable` to `RegistrySnapshot` since the name was very misleading. Actual routing table is created from a registry snapshot after the health checks are done
* Remove latency/success_rate moving average calculations since they're not used anywhere now (we just pick a random node). Can be brought back from git history if needed at some point
* Don't get `nns_subnet_id` from registry (was never used)
* Change some API's (like `persist` can never fail, no point in having it return `Result` , also it doesn't need a full snapshot, just a list of subnets)
* Some other smaller things that I probably forgot 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15271
perf(BOUN-908): refactor & optimize ic-boundary a bit

Merge branch 'igornovg/icbn-memory' into 'master'

feat(BOUN-908): ic-boundary: snapshot metrics periodically

Currently, metrics are generated on-the-fly when the `GET /metrics` request arrives. This takes time, allocates a lot of memory and is executed for every scraper that comes (and there are quite a few) which is sub-optimal if the metrics are rather big.

Instead we'll run a job to generate & encode a snapshot of the text-representation into a pre-allocated buffer and only output it in the handler. This should relieve the memory allocator and make the things faster overall. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15244
feat(BOUN-908): ic-boundary: snapshot metrics periodically

Merge branch 'igornovg/icbn-metrics' into 'master'

feat(BOUN-897): ic-boundary metrics and some refactoring

Ok folks, sorry for the mess, it's a lot of changes, I hope once we are feature-rich it won't be like that anymore...

* Cache bypass reasons added, might be removed in future once we're happy
* Add compression layer to both `/metrics` endpoint and to proxied calls. This reduces the transfer size of a Prometheus scrape down to 5% of the original
* Remove TLS verify / DNS resolve metrics, instead extend `ErrorCause` with specific TLS/DNS errors (see `reqwest_error_infer` function)
* Reduce the number of Histogram buckets to reduce the metrics cardinality (actually I think was done in prev MR, but not mentioned)
* Remove logging of status calls and introduce a separate metric for them: `ic_boundary_http_request_status_total`
* Remove one of counters for full response streaming duration since it's very customer-specific and depends on his internet connection
* Factor out node lookup from `preprocess_request` into a separate middleware (\`lookup_node\`) and remove node and canister_id from RequestContext. This is needed for better composability and plugging in between stuff like bitcoin-specific routing

Overall I expect metrics to shrink to some 40%, not taking the compression into account. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15188
feat(BOUN-897): ic-boundary metrics and some refactoring

Merge branch 'igornovg/icbn-cache' into 'master'

feat(BOUN-891) Implement query caching in ic-boundary

Base caching features implemented:

* Settings: Memory limit, max response size to cache, TTL
* Disabled by default (memory limit needs to be set)
* Caches only query calls without a `nonce` specified
* Cache key: `sender` + `canister_id` + `method_name` + `ingress_expiry` + `arg`
* Currently it caches all queries regardless of whether they're anonymous or not (to be discussed)
* Honor `Cache-Control` header and emit `x-ic-cache-status` header with a `HIT`/ `MISS` / `SKIP`. There's a `Cache-Status` header but it does not seem to be widely used, so let's use custom for now.
* Metic label for cache status

Also:

* Some bit of refactoring how the middlewares are organized so that the cache fits there better. 
* Reduce number of histogram buckets to make metrics smaller, more to be done here 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15075
feat(BOUN-891) Implement query caching in ic-boundary

Merge branch 'igornovg/ic-bn-metrics' into 'master'

feat(BOUN-884): Add response metrics to ic-boundary and fix icx-proxy

Add an improved `MetricsBody` from `icx-proxy` to `ic-boundary` that handles certain edge cases and backport fixes to `icx-proxy`

* Response sizes are now counted properly instead of relying on `Content-Length` that in a lot of cases is absent
* Also `full_duration` is additionally observed that corresponds to the time it takes a client to receive the response. Before we were only measuring the response generation time 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!14895
feat(BOUN-884): Add response metrics to ic-boundary and fix icx-proxy

Merge branch 'igornovg/icx-proxy-metrics' into 'master'

BOUN-868 Add HTTP metrics to icx-proxy

* Implement `MetricsBody` wrapper over `HttpBody` to count the chunks' size that get streamed to a client and issue a callback whenever the job is done. This needs to be moved to a some shared place later to be reused by `ic-boundary` also.
* Add HTTP metrics with labels like `streaming` which indicates if a response was using IC streaming and `body_fully_read` which indicates if we successfully read the body from replica (no easy way to check if client actually received it). Proper buckets are used for Histograms that are based on some quick Clickhouse analysis e.g.

  ```sql
  SELECT
      count() AS cnt,
      request_time_ms - (request_time_ms % 100) AS sz
  FROM http_access_distributed
  WHERE date > (now() - toIntervalDay(1 AND (request_time_ms < 10000)))
  GROUP BY sz
  ORDER BY cnt DESC
  ```
* Add `X-IC-Streaming-Response` header to replies that indicates if the response used streaming ( `true` / `false` ) -\> this can be used in `ic-boundary` / `nginx` in logging/metrics to add this info to Clickhouse for later analysis 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!14845
BOUN-868 Add HTTP metrics to icx-proxy

Merge branch 'igornovg/icbn-status' into 'master'

(BOUN-873): Fix ic-boundary status call

* Add self-describing tag to a `status` response to match the behaviour of replicas
* Add `application/cbor` content-type header to all responses
* As a side hustle change `status_code` label in outgoing HTTP metrics to be `000` instead of an empty string to make Prometheus feel better (it displays weird stuff for empty labels in Grafana) 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!14804
(BOUN-873): Fix ic-boundary status call

Merge branch 'igornovg/fix-opentelem' into 'master'

[BOUN-836][BOUN-869][BOUN-862]: ic-boundary: drop opentelemetry

Drop usage of `opentelemetry` crate, stick with just `prometheus`

We were using OpenTelemetry wrong in `control-plane` (calling `observe()` on Gauge directly and not in callback) and that led to undefined behaviour in `0.20`

Start with migrating `ic-boundary` , later we can move other services and `control-plane` too, or just leave it as is and let it die.

P.S. There's also a mix of changes by @kobi-lizard to roll other services back to older `opentelemetry` crate. I can try to divide the changes if needed. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!14581
[BOUN-836][BOUN-869][BOUN-862]: ic-boundary: drop opentelemetry

Merge branch 'igornovg/icbn-testing' into 'master'

BOUN-826: Improve ic-boundary testing

No real changes, just moving code around.

* Rearrange tests into separate files
* Reorganize some code
* Re-enable some tests that were disabled for some reason 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!14513
BOUN-826: Improve ic-boundary testing

Merge branch 'igornovg/vector-improve' into 'master'

BOUN-865: update vector config

* Increase in-memory buffer size to lower probability of data loss. This should not consume more than 300MB memory when full
* Change full buffer logic to `block` -\> `drop_newest` not recommended for in memory buffers and we want to backpressure this to vector's source
* Increase batch size and timeout to create less parts in Clickhouse (less frequent and larger inserts)
* Decrease retry interval to have less pressure when there are problems 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!14507
BOUN-865: update vector config

Merge branch 'BOUN-841-manual-performance-query-test' into 'master'

(BOUN-841) add performance query_calls_test()

**How to run**: 
1. Reserve the `dm1` host machine on Dee.
2. Execute:
```sh
ict test boundary_node_performance_test --include-tests=query_calls_test --keepalive
```
`Rps` was varied in the range `100:500:8000` req/s and the maximum observed throughput on the replica is around 7k req/s.
The profile doesn't exactly exhibit staircase shape, as one would expect. Some strange dips (e.g. at 5.5 k req/s) are observed. I haven't investigated what causes it. It might be due to the problem with the client (workload engine) or anything from `ngingx` on the boundary node to replica. We can dissect this problem deeper in the followup work. For now that fact that we observe >4k req/s is good enough.
![image](/uploads/cf4ff0ba56be37e5bb5eaedc89c17b58/image.png) 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!14228

Merge branch 'alic/fix-upgrade-test2' into 'master'

fix(consensus): [ICSUP-3714] Change upgrade cycle in upgrade_downgrade test (fixed)

Fix of reverted MR: https://gitlab.com/dfinity-lab/public/ic/-/merge_requests/15563

I had to get the proper tip-of-branch replica version from the env variable, instead of hardcoding to `0000000000000000000000000000000000000000`. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15723
fix(consensus): [ICSUP-3714] Change upgrade cycle in upgrade_downgrade test (fixed)

Merge branch 'alic/fix-upgrade-test' into 'master'

fix(consensus): [ICSUP-3714] Change upgrade cycle in upgrade_downgrade test

We've been observing test failures on staging that should have happened on CI. This discrepancy was caused by the difference in upgrade cycle. 

- During qualification, we do a `mainnet` -> `RC` -> `mainnet` upgrade-downgrade roundtrip. 
- In this test however, we've been doing `RC` -> `mainnet` -> `RC`. Even though we're testing both upgrade directions, there's still subtle opportunities for failure. 

This MR fixes the upgrade cycle, so that we start from `mainnet`.


Additionally, to verify that the changes work as expected, I've ran this patch on RC `1ad201eb530a5c572bc72d302160783e7fb4c60b` and attempted to downgrade to the mainnet version from that time (`ca5e5052886de781021506814d2c6502e375da48`). I could reproduce the failure we observed during qualification.

- Bazel logs: https://dash.zh1-idx1.dfinity.network/invocation/d53b7724-cc17-4f4f-9280-8e67953ad487
- Kibana logs: [Upgrade failure messages](https://kibana.testnet.dfinity.network/app/discover#/?_g=(time:(from:now-1y,to:now))&_a=(columns:!(host.name,message,level),filters:!(('$state':(store:appState),meta:(alias:!n,disabled:!f,key:tags,negate:!f,params:(query:upgrade_downgrade_app_subnet_test--1698343603734),type:phrase),query:(match_phrase:(tags:upgrade_downgrade_app_subnet_test--1698343603734))),('$state':(store:appState),meta:(alias:!n,disabled:!f,index:'35c5ba4b-6db5-42f6-a760-39ca89a177fe',key:message,negate:!f,params:(query:'Check%20for%20upgrade%20failed:%20Ok(Err(GenericError(%22Failed%20to%20upgrade:%20upgrade-install%20failed%22)))'),type:phrase),query:(match_phrase:(message:'Check%20for%20upgrade%20failed:%20Ok(Err(GenericError(%22Failed%20to%20upgrade:%20upgrade-install%20failed%22)))')))),grid:(columns:(host.name:(width:513))),index:'35c5ba4b-6db5-42f6-a760-39ca89a177fe',interval:auto,query:(language:kuery,query:'syslog.identifier:%22orchestrator%22%20'),sort:!(!('@timestamp',desc)))) 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15563
fix(consensus): [ICSUP-3714] Change upgrade cycle in upgrade_downgrade test

doc: Add guidelines for replicated state invariants

In !16020 a new option for handling errors upon deserializing the state was introduced. This MR adds the guideline on when to use this new option and when other variants are preferrable. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!16063
doc: Add guidelines for replicated state invariants

Merge branch 'dderler/critical-error-metrics' into 'master'

chore: Allow raising critical error metrics during checkpoint loading

So far the only option for checking invariants of datastructures during checkpoint loading was to check them upon deserialization and return an error in case of a violation. This does in further consequence crash the replica. This is fine for invariants where the violation would affect correctness of the code and there is no meaningful way to move on. 

With the introduction of blockmaker metrics it became apparent that there are some properties of datastructures which we aim to maintain all the time, but their violation does not affect correctness. For such errors -- we call them soft invariants in this MR -- it is more desirable to bump an error counter and move on with deserialization.

This MR introduces a mechanism to allow bumping critical error counters upon deserialization and applies this to the blockmaker metrics starts. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!16020
chore: Allow raising critical error metrics during checkpoint loading

Merge branch 'dderler/subnet-splitting/follow-1267' into 'master'

[FOLLOW-1267] Assert data can fit into single chunk when appending single chunk file to split manifest

When splitting manifests for subnet splitting we have several instances where hashes corresponding to single chunk files need to be computed and appended to the manifest. This MR adds an assert that fires if the number of bytes in such a file exceeds `DEFAULT_CHUNK_SIZE` to ensure that the resulting manifest is valid. This assert will also make several tests fail in case the serialized representations of the respective data structures ever become too big due to future code changes. Thus, such an issue would already be noticed on CI as opposed to directly when a split is ongoing.

Closes FOLLOW-1267 

Closes FOLLOW-1267

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15266
[FOLLOW-1267] Assert data can fit into single chunk when appending single chunk file to split manifest

Merge branch 'dderler/state-tool-remove-obsolete-canister-hash' into 'master'

chore: Remove obsolete canister_hash function in state_tool

The `canister_hash` function of the state tool was used to compute a hash of a canister that that is independent of its index in the file table of the manifest. Using the canister hash it was possible to tell whether two canisters in two different states are the same, based on whether or not their canister hashes matched. As of manifest version `V3` file hashes in manifests are independent of their index in the file table and so this functionality is no longer required -- hashes of files related to the same canister in two different states will match out of the box. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!14157
chore: Remove obsolete canister_hash function in state_tool

Merge branch 'shuo/hash_of_nested_map' into 'master'

feat: hash_of_map supports nested Map

This MR extend the `hash_of_map` function to support compute the hash of nested Map.

1. extend `Enum RawHttpRequestVal` with new variant Map
2. implement the hash_val method for Map
3. hashing only takes references. This avoids unnecessary clone of values at each level of the nested Map
4. use this new way to compute the response hash
5. add unit tests to guard hash_of_map from potential future accidental changes
6. update spec compliance test for the new functionality and response hash

Merge branch 'eero/sev-prep' into 'master'

feat(NODE-1182,NODE-1183): SEV feature tooling

**In `ic-admin`:**

Launch measurement can now be passed to `propose-to-update-elected-replica-versions` with:
```
bazel run //rs/registry/admin:ic-admin -- --nns-url "<NNS_URL>" propose-to-update-elected-replica-versions --replica-version-to-elect <VERSION> --release-package-sha256-hex <HASH> --release-package-urls <URL> --guest-launch-measurement <MEASUREMENT> --summary "Elect version with measurement"
```
And the SEV subnet feature can be set during subnet creation with:
```
bazel run //rs/registry/admin:ic-admin -- --nns-url "<NNS_URL>" propose-to-create-subnet --subnet-type <TYPE> --features sev_enabled <SUBNET> --summary "Create SEV subnet"
```

**In `ic-prep`:**

Launch measurement could already be set with:
```
--guest-launch-measurement-sha256-hex <MEASUREMENT>
```
And now the SEV subnet feature can be set with:
```
--sev-subnet-indices 1,2
```

Both are already available through the Rust API.

---

I've also replaced the feature `sev_status` with `sev_enabled` to simplify now that we don't plan to use multiple stages for rollout. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!16162

Merge branch 'kb/p2p-sev-handshake' into 'master'

feat(NODE-701): Load certs if missing for snp report verification

For prod, the certs will be injected via config from the host. But if the certs are not injected or for testnet, the certs are fetched from AMD-SP via SNP_GET_EXT_REPORT ioctl. 
ARK.pem is hardcoded as it is the root of trust. We want to decrease our reliance on AMD server. ARK endpoint is also rate limited. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15885
feat(NODE-701): Load certs if missing for snp report verification

Merge branch 'kb/cleanup' into 'master'

feat(NODE-1137): SEV-SNP library cleanup

Cleanup sev library. Rename sev to snp to distinguish between sev and icos sev libraries. Remove reference to sevtool. Also remove icos_sev_interface and move the interfaces(pub errors and traits) to newly renamed snp library. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15526
feat(NODE-1137): SEV-SNP library cleanup

Merge branch 'kb/att_report' into 'master'

feat(NODE-1139): Add chip_id to AddNodePayload during node registration

Chip_id is added to the AddNodePayload to be sent during node registration. This MR does these:
1. sevctl is a wrapper around sev library. It has been renamed to snptool to avoid confusion with virtee/sevctl which does not support SEV-SNP.
2. sev library is bumped to version 1.2.1 which supports the 6.1-snp kernel on ic-os.
3. Orchestrator calls the ic_icos_sev crate which relies on sev library to derive the chip_id.
4. Chip_id is now an optional field in the registry. 

Tested on dev-sev and dev targets. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15449
feat(NODE-1139): Add chip_id to AddNodePayload during node registration
fix: two issues with SEV GuestOS

Merge branch 'kb/update_guestos_1' into 'master'

feat(NODE-1020): Bring up guestos as a SEV-SNP VM

sev-guest.service launches a qemu based SEV-SNP GuestOS. If host is built for SEV target, the qemu script is generated and the sev-guest is launched.
Tested on zh2-asu01 and zh2-asu02.
TODO: The generation of the qemu script and launch of GuestOS should be done by the hostos agent. This will be done as part of NODE-748. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!13699

In this MR we remove the obsolete `DkgId` and `IDkgId` types that predate genesis. In the process we also change the threshold signing and verify API to take a `NiDkgId` instead of the obsolete wrapper type. This closes the remaining open points from CRP-1078 and CRP-1079.

Merge branch 'stefan/1502-adapter_criterion_benchmark_e2e' into 'master'

feat[NET-1514]: adapter criterion e2e benchmark

This simulation constructs a blockchain comprising four forks, each of 2000 blocks. For an extended BFS execution, the initial 1975 blocks of every branch are marked as being processed in the request, with the aim to receive the last 25 blocks of each fork. Performance metrics are captured from the sending of the deserialised request through to receiving the response and its deserialisation.

On average, the simulation completes in approximately 19 ms, occasionally reaching highs of 21 ms and dipping to lows of 17 ms.

It can be run using:
`bazel run //rs/bitcoin/adapter:e2e_bench` 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!14099

Merge branch 'nathan/run-sw-e2e-tests-on-pipeline' into 'master'

ci: run service worker e2e tests

#TT-232

To test this on the devenv:

SSH into a devenv (make sure SSH keys are forwarded)
Clone the IC repo

Checkout this branch:
```shell
git checkout nathan/run-sw-e2e-tests-on-pipeline
``` 

Start the container (this is the same container used by the CI):
```shell
./gitlab-ci/container/container-run.sh -f
```

Change to the service worker directory:
```shell
cd ./typescript/service-worker
```

Run e2e tests:
```
./e2e/e2e --add-dependencies --start --run-tests --stop
```

fix(service-worker): inline load of response-verification wasm

#TT-298

This fixes the issue where an old service worker that is running on the page would try to load the new `wasm` file from a recently deployed service worker, this would previously fail. With this change i move the `wasm` of response verification to be inline loaded.

Before the `sw.js` file had 258kb and then loaded the `wasm` that had 242kb, with this change the `sw.js` with the included `wasm` have 580kb.

Merge branch 'gary/NODE-908-network-config' into 'master'

fix: NODE-908 - Flexible Network Configuration Behavior

Similar to guestos_tool, setupos_tool is a rust binary that aims to replace various shell scripts. 
This MR targets network configuration logic. 

* Fixes the long running issue of needing two eth cables plugged in
* * Ipv6 connectivity is now tested all interfaces. The fastest valid connected ipv6 interface is used. 
* Deduplicates network configuration logic between HostOS and SetupOS
* Adds unit tests (!)

Testing has been done to match the behavior of the previous generate-deterministic-* scripts. See the related unit tests and [NODE-908](https://dfinity.atlassian.net/browse/NODE-908) for manual testing notes.

Merge branch 'gary/export-podman-tar' into 'master'

fix: Use podman to export the IC-OS filesystems.

https://dfinity.atlassian.net/browse/NODE-973

docker_tar.py was complex. This simplifies it by using `podman export` instead. A surprise bug was fixed because of this - several (hundreds) of symlinks on *OS were broken (but happened to not be used). This fixes them. Those files and possibly parent packages will be considered for removal.

The relevant bazel targets are simplified as much as possible. More to come. 

Bazel is complex. Guiding principle: make it simpler, easier to understand, easier to make future modifications and easier to debug. This comes at the cost of duplication sometimes. E.g., the myriad config files are files and not generated by a bazel target or python thing. But you can feed those config files directly to build_container_filesystem_tar.py on the command line.

UPDATE:
LOTS of testing ensued because `podman export` and `podman build` invocation changes kicked up known concurrency bugs in podman 3.x. These are fixed in podman 4.x. But we're not getting that version soon.
Now separate system directories are used for each podman invocation. This works on CI and on multi-user systems. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!13136
fix: Use podman to export the IC-OS filesystems.

Merge branch 'nikola-milosavljevic/service-discovery-v2' into 'master'

feat: Service discovery v2

To run `multiservice_discovery`: `cargo run -- --targets-dir ~/tmp/multiservice_discovery`

Features:
* New discovery is split in definitions (these are related to a network, for e.g. mainnet, testnet a, testnet b,...).
* New discovery has an http server running on port 8000 which can be used to `GET` current definitions with its jobs and filters, to `POST` new definitions with jobs and filters and to `DELETE` (for e.g. `DELETE /testet1 HTTP/1.1`) to delete definition by name. 

Notes:
* one cannot remove `mainnet` definition which is there by default
* name of the definition has to be unique
* deleting a definition will delete its registry

To run `multiservice_discovery_downloader`: `cargo run -- --output-dir ~/tmp/multiservice_discovery_output --sd-url http://localhost:8000/targets --generator log --filter-node-id-regex ^a.*`

Features:
* Has the ability to filter targets based on node id
* Only writes to disk if the hash of the targets changed 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!14851
feat: Service discovery v2

Merge branch 'alexuta/run-799' into 'master'

[RUN-799] Enable new instrumentation on verified app subnets.

New instrumentation has been running successfully on application subnets. We now enable it on verified app subnets. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!15631
[RUN-799] Enable new instrumentation on verified app subnets.

Merge branch 'mk/charge_for_dirty_heap_a_test' into 'master'

[RUN-792] Enable new WASM metering on Application subnets

The new instrumentation is enabled by merging this MR. The instrumentation has been [presented to the community](https://forum.dfinity.org/t/new-wasm-instrumentation/22080) and the community has voted positively for the [NNS motion](https://dashboard.internetcomputer.org/proposal/124816) that proposes to enable it on mainnet. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!14032

Merge branch 'alexuta/double_query_threads_everywhere' into 'master'

[RUN-699] Double amount of total query threads for all subnet types

This is part of the larger feature regarding the file-backed allocator. This was recently enabled on all types of subnets and therefore we can also double the number of query threads. Application subnets have been running successfully for the past few months with the file backed allocator and 4 query threads in total with good performance and no known regressions. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!14212
[RUN-699] Double amount of total query threads for all subnet types

Merge branch 'alexuta/enable_fb_allocator' into 'master'

Enable File-backed Allocator on all subnets

This MR enables the file-backed allocator on all subnets. We have done extensive performance testing and there are no known regressions. Also, the file-backed allocator has run successfully on mainnet for application subnets in the last few months without any performance degradation. 

See merge request dfinity-lab/public/ic!14184
Enable File-backed Allocator on all subnets

Merge branch 'martin/chore-uvm-add-mcopy-rule' into 'master'

chore(bazel,uvm-image): add mcopy rule [IDX-2973]

This MR adds a mcopy rule. This rule receives the files from srcs and remap_path the remap filenames. The tar and untar rules are still used to calculate the size of the vfat image.

### Current master:
```
ubuntu@devenv-container:/ic$ ls bazel-out/k8-opt/bin/rs/tests/custom_domains_uvm_config_image_untar
bazel-out/k8-opt/bin/rs/tests/custom_domains_uvm_config_image_untar:
activate  cloudflare_api.py  coredns.tar  openssl.tar  pebble.tar  pebble_cache.py  python3.tar

ubuntu@devenv-container:/ic$ fatcat bazel-out/k8-opt/bin/rs/tests/custom_domains_uvm_config_image_uncompressed -l /
Listing path /
Directory cluster: 0
f 19/10/2023 08:06:04  ACTIVATE                       c=2 s=314 (314B)
f 19/10/2023 08:06:04  cloudflare_api.py              c=3 s=14789 (14.4424K)
f 19/10/2023 08:06:04  COREDNS.TAR                    c=5 s=53627904 (51.1436M)
f 19/10/2023 08:06:04  OPENSSL.TAR                    c=6552 s=8330752 (7.94482M)
f 19/10/2023 08:06:04  PEBBLE.TAR                     c=7569 s=17437184 (16.6294M)
f 19/10/2023 08:06:04  pebble_cache.py                c=9698 s=8345 (8.14941K)
f 19/10/2023 08:06:04  PYTHON3.TAR                    c=9700 s=55032320 (52.4829M)
```

### This branch
```
ubuntu@devenv-container:/ic$ ls bazel-out/k8-opt/bin/rs/tests/custom_domains_uvm_config_image_untar
bazel-out/k8-opt/bin/rs/tests/custom_domains_uvm_config_image_untar:
activate  cloudflare_api.py  coredns.tar  openssl.tar  pebble.tar  pebble_cache.py  python3.tar

ubuntu@devenv-container:/ic$ fatcat bazel-out/k8-opt/bin/rs/tests/custom_domains_uvm_config_image_mcopy -l /
Listing path /
Directory cluster: 0
f 19/10/2023 11:13:24  COREDNS.TAR                    c=2 s=53627904 (51.1436M)
f 19/10/2023 11:13:22  OPENSSL.TAR                    c=6549 s=8330752 (7.94482M)
f 19/10/2023 11:13:22  PEBBLE.TAR                     c=7566 s=17437184 (16.6294M)
f 19/10/2023 11:13:22  PYTHON3.TAR                    c=9695 s=55032320 (52.4829M)
f 29/8/2023 13:22:40  ACTIVATE                       c=16413 s=314 (314B)
f 29/8/2023 13:22:40  pebble_cache.py                c=16414 s=8345 (8.14941K)
f 13/10/2023 07:14:52  cloudflare_api.py              c=16416 s=14789 (14.4424K)
```

Merge branch 'martin/fix-build-reprod' into 'master'

fix(IDX-2905): build reproducibility

Script `build-diff.sh` is broken since were on K8s and further more, doing diffoscope is slow if we feed `*.img` directly to it. Its more efficient to create loop device, mount it under dir and run diffoscope on that dir.  

It seems to make more sense to provide good instructions how to create loop device of the image, mount it's partition somewhere and run `diffoscope` on it. We can consider automating this and providing means any person can run this on GitHub via GH Actions, once we're fully on GH.

It also adds some metrics related to the size of the indices.
